'Dopamine-responsive dystonia' ('DRD'), also known as 'hereditary progressive
dystonia with diurnal fluctuation', 'Segawa's disease', or 'Segawa's dystonia',
is a genetic movement disorder which usually manifests itself during early
childhood at around ages 5â8 years (variable start age).

Characteristic symptoms are increased muscle tone (dystonia, such as clubfoot)
and Parkinsonian features, typically absent in the morning or after rest but
worsening during the day and with exertion. Children with DRD are often
misdiagnosed as having cerebral palsy. The disorder responds well to treatment
with levodopa.
